message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Osgood-Schlatter disease is characterized by pain and tenderness below the patella, often in young athletes, due to repetitive stress on the growth plate. The pain is aggravated by jumping or climbing stairs, which matches the patient’s symptoms. Meniscal tear, patellofemoral syndrome, and prepatellar bursitis would typically have different symptoms and physical examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain in the patient’s knee below the kneecap and the history of frequent jumping activities are characteristic of Osgood-Schlatter disease, which is caused by repetitive stress on the patellar tendon. No other options match these symptoms. The pain reproduced when the knee is extended against resistance supports this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain is exacerbated by jumping activity and climbing stairs, which suggests Osgood-Schlatter disease. Meniscal tear usually occurs after an injury, and patients typically experience locking or catching of the knee joint. Patellofemoral syndrome is typically characterized by anterior knee pain that is worsened by activities such as squatting, kneeling, and climbing stairs. Prepatellar bursitis causes pain and swelling over the front of the knee, but it is usually associated with a history of trauma or prolonged kneeling.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Osgood-Schlatter disease is a common cause of knee pain in adolescents, especially those involved in physical activities that require a lot of jumping. The pain is typically located below the kneecap and worsened with activity. The pain is also reproduced when extending the knee against resistance, which is consistent with the examination finding in this patient. The other options are less likely based on the patient's presentation and examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Osgood-Schlatter disease, which is common in adolescent athletes experiencing growth spurts, especially those who play basketball or volleyball. The pain is exacerbated by jumping and climbing stairs, and there is no history of knee injury. The pain is reproduced when the knee is extended against resistance, which is a common test for Osgood-Schlatter disease. Meniscal tear usually presents with locking and catching of the knee joint, while patellofemoral syndrome causes pain behind or around the kneecap. Prepatellar bursitis usually presents with swelling and tenderness in the front of the knee, and there is usually a history of knee trauma or prolonged kneeling.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s age, activity level, and location of pain suggest Osgood-Schlatter disease. The pain is reproduced with resisted extension, which is a hallmark of this condition. None of the other options match the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of jumping activity and pain below the kneecap suggests Osgood-Schlatter disease, which is common among young athletes. Pain with knee extension against resistance is a common symptom of this disease. All other options may involve different locations for pain and different types of movements that exacerbate the pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are consistent with Osgood-Schlatter disease, which is characterized by pain below the kneecap, especially during activities that involve jumping or running. The pain is typically reproduced with knee extension against resistance. Meniscal tear would present with joint line tenderness, locking or popping sensation, and difficulty fully extending the knee. Patellofemoral syndrome would cause anterior knee pain worsened by ascending and descending stairs or sitting for prolonged periods, and Prepatellar bursitis would present with swelling and tenderness over the prepatellar region.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s age and history of recent basketball activity suggests that the most likely diagnosis is Osgood-Schlatter disease, a common cause of knee pain in young athletes. The pain is exacerbated by activity and can be reproduced when the knee is extended against resistance. Meniscal tear typically involves locking or catching of the knee joint, and patellofemoral syndrome typically presents with dull pain around the kneecap. Prepatellar bursitis presents with swelling and tenderness at the front of the kneecap.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain, below the kneecap, and its association with jumping activities, suggest Osgood-Schlatter disease. The pain is reproduced when the knee is extended against resistance, which is a hallmark of this condition. All other options are less likely given the patient's history and physical examination findings.
